feed.title: NewsTracker: tsipras
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras heads Tuesday to Brussels, where he will try to use a bailout referendum victory to obtain a rescue deal with European leaders.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras races to restart talks after vote win
entry.summary:
Tsipras faces intense pressure from creditors abroad and banks at home who all demand what Greece lacks: money.

In a sign of compromise, Tsipras appointed a new finance minister to lead talks with creditors and replace Yanis Varoufakis, who clashed with his European counterparts.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, left, leaves a polling station after voting in Athens, Sunday, July 5, 2015.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
entry.summary:
Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras won big in Sunday's referendum, in which 60 percent of Greeks rejected the economic measures creditors had proposed in exchange for loans the country needs to remain afloat.

That meeting is meant to seek the basis for a deal that European leaders, including Tsipras, might discuss at an emergency summit later in the day.

Ahead of the summit, Tsipras spoke by phone with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Tsipras has agreed to imposing more harsh austerity measures, following a six-year recession, but wants eurozone lenders to grant the country better terms for bailout debt repayments.

entry.title: After vote win, Greece's Tsipras looks to rebuild talks
Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Already, Tsipras' coalition is under strain as a succession of deputies from the right-wing Independent Greeks, his junior partners, have backed the 'Yes' vote.

entry.title: Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Tsipras may not survive long if voters ignore his call to vote 'No'.

entry.title: Tsipras dismisses Europe's warnings to Greece on vote
entry.summary: Tsipras is betting Europe will compromise rather than let Greece slip out of the eurozone, even though the continent's leaders say a "No" vote would signal its exit.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras says IMF report fully justifies Greece's position on debt relief
Greece's Tsipras digs in against bailout
entry.summary:
Less than 24 hours after he wrote a conciliatory letter to creditors asking for a new bailout that would accept many of their terms, Tsipras abruptly switched back into combative mode in a television address.

Euro zone finance ministers held an hour-long conference call to discuss the previous night's offer from Tsipras, but were adamant that no further discussions would be held until after Sunday's vote.

In his overnight letter to creditors, seen by Reuters, Tsipras agreed to accept most of their demands for taxes and pension cuts and asked for a new 29 billion euro loan to cover all debt service payments in the next two years.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras digs in against bailout
entry.summary:
"We will come back to your request for financial stability support from the ESM (European Stability Mechanism) only after, and on the basis of the outcome of, the referendum," the head of the currency zone ministers' Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, wrote in a letter to Tsipras.

Tsipras has suggested he would step aside if Greeks vote "Yes" in Sunday's referendum.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greece's parliament voted early Sunday in favor of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' motion to hold a July 5 referendum on creditor proposals for reforms in exchange for loans.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Tsipras called the referendum over the weekend, arguing that demands for tougher austerity measures could not be accepted after six years of recession.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was defiant, urging voters to reject creditors' demands, insisting a "No" vote in next Sunday's referendum would strengthen Athens' negotiating hand.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary:
Tsipras says the Bank of Greece has recommended that banks remain closed and restrictions be imposed on transactions, after the European Central Bank didn't increase the amount of emergency liquidity the lenders can access from the central bank.

In this photo taken from ERT State Television, Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras delivers a televised address to the nation from his office at Maximos Mansion in Athens, Sunday, June 28, 2015.

entry.title: Tsipras defiant as banks shut, markets rocked
entry.summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, right, speaks with journalist Panos Haritos before a TV interview at the State Television (ERT) in Athens, Monday, June 29, 2015.

entry.title: Greece to introduce capital controls, keep banks shut as crisis deepens
entry.summary: The creditors want Greece to cut pensions and raise taxes in ways that Tsipras has long argued would deepen one of the worst economic crises of modern times in a country where a quarter of the workforce is already unemployed.

entry.title: Greek minister calls on nation to reject bailout deal
entry.summary: Lafazanis spoke early Saturday, after an emergency cabinet meeting during which Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced his intention to call the referendum.

entry.title: IMF quits Greek talks; EU tells Tsipras: stop gambling
entry.summary: Tsipras told reporters he had worked on bridging the remaining differences on fiscal and financing issues.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras presents new financial proposal to EU
entry.summary:
A government source close to the talks says Tsipras "presented to the three leaders Greece's proposal for a mutually beneficial agreement, which will provide a permanent solution and not just postpone tackling the problem."

Tsipras has been meeting with his senior ministers all day and will leave for Brussels later Sunday.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras presented proposal to EU leaders: PM's office
Pressing for Greek concessions, Merkel and Hollande keep Tsipras waiting
entry.summary: The European Commission said its chief, Jean-Claude Juncker, who accused Tsipras on Sunday of misrepresenting the creditors' proposals and misleading his parliament, had no plans as yet to meet the Greek premier either.

entry.title: Greek Premier Tsipras, ministers discuss strategy, proposals for next week's Eurozone summit
Greek officials meet, prepare proposals for Eurozone summit
entry.summary: A meeting between Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and three senior ministers finished Saturday evening and a new one is scheduled for Sunday morning.

entry.title: Greek premier Tsipras, ministers discuss strategy, proposals for next week's Eurozone summit
entry.summary:
Minister of State Alekos Flambouraris said in a TV interview earlier Saturday that there could be a phone discussion between Tsipras and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker later Saturday, although it had not been scheduled yet.

The government on Saturday said Tsipras has cancelled a visit to Strasbourg Tuesday, where he was scheduled to speak at the Council of Europe.

entry.title: ECB boosts emergency funding as Greek banks bleed, Tsipras calm
entry.summary: Greek officials said Tsipras, who returns from a visit to Russia on Saturday, would spend the weekend preparing Greece's position at the summit but the pressure on his government is coming at least as much from the banks as from the lenders.

entry.title: Greek Premier Tsipras says no elections or referendum, whatever the outcome of bailout talks
entry.summary:
ATHENS, Greece - A government official says Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has told senior aides to "forget about elections or a referendum," whatever the outcome of the country's talks with creditors.

The official said Tsipras told four senior ministers Friday that his government, elected last January, has a fresh popular mandate and that "people have trusted us to take crucial decisions and manage the difficulties."

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity due to the sensitivity of the talks, on Saturday quoted Tsipras as saying his government would deal with an agreement with creditors "however difficult the compromise."

entry.title: Tsipras seeks debt relief as Greeks take offer to Brussels
entry.summary:
Tsipras, who was elected in January on promises to end austerity, made it clear he was willing to give ground but with strings attached that German Chancellor Angela Merkel is unlikely to accept.

Tsipras signaled that without debt relief, he would reject any deal involving curbs on the right of Greek workers to bargain collectively on pay - something that union members elsewhere take for granted.

entry.title: Tsipras seeks debt relief as Greeks take offer to Brussels
Tsipras seeks debt relief as Greeks take offer to Brussels
entry.summary: Tsipras used the term "sustainable solution" to refer to a long-standing demand for large parts of Greece's mountainous debts to be written off - something he believes is vital if the Greek economy is to start getting back on its feet after a five-year depression.

entry.title: IMF quits Greek talks; EU tells Tsipras: stop gambling
entry.summary: Tsipras held two hours of talks with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, but neither side reported any breakthrough.

entry.title: IMF quits Greek talks; EU tells Tsipras: stop gambling
IMF quits Greek talks; EU tells Tsipras: stop gambling
entry.summary: "Come in the torture room," Juncker told Tsipras at the start of their meeting.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras under pressure for concessions in debt talks
entry.summary: A poll showed a slight rise since April in the number who are dissatisfied with Tsipras's negotiating performance with the creditors, reaching 53.4 percent from 50.5 percent.

entry.title: Greece PM Pressured for Debt Talk Concessions
entry.summary:
Tsipras again said he saw a solution at hand.

Tsipras renewed a call for a restructuring of Athens' debts as part of any solution.

entry.title: Greek leader heads to Brussels to meet Merkel, Hollande
entry.summary:
However, Merkel recently indicated she would have an opportunity to speak to Tsipras on Wednesday.

Tsipras must also face down hardliners within his own party, many of which have called for a break in relations with creditors and for Greece to go it alone, even if it means leaving the euro.

entry.title: Greek PM heads to Brussels, hoping to end bailout stalemate
entry.summary: However, Schinas said Moscovici had informed the government Tuesday afternoon "that their latest suggestions do not reflect the state of discussions between President Juncker and Prime Minister Tsipras Wednesday night and those between Commissioner Moscovici and the Greek ministers Monday afternoon."

entry.title: Greek leader heads to Brussels to meet Merkel, Hollande
entry.summary: Tsipras' radical left Syriza party won early elections in January on promises of repealing the harsh austerity measures that accompanied Greece's 240 billion euro bailout program.

entry.title: Tsipras sees Greek deal, but differences remain after EU talks
entry.summary:
But as Tsipras's party battles to retain support from voters who elected in January to end years of austerity, its spokesman in parliament renewed tough rhetoric at home.

Tsipras, whose government has been critical of a hard line from the IMF, again praised Juncker's executive for showing understanding of the Greek predicament.

entry.title: Tsipras sees Greek deal, but differences remain after EU talks
entry.summary:
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras (L) poses with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker ahead of a meeting at the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, June 3, 2015.

However, Tsipras has produced a plan of his own and said he intended to discuss that document in Brussels, calling on euro zone partners to show some "realism" and urging a deal that would let Greece escape from "economic asphyxiation".

entry.title: Tsipras sees Greek deal, but differences remain after EU talks
entry.summary: "At the end of the day," Tsipras said, "I think the proposals on the table will be the proposals of the Greek government."

entry.title: Greek leader heads to Brussels to defend deal proposal
entry.summary:
Ahead of his meeting with Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker, Alexis Tsipras stressed the need for compromise.

"I will go to ... explain to him that today more than ever it is necessary for the (creditor) institutions and mainly for the political leadership of Europe to sign up to realism," Tsipras said before leaving for Brussels.

Speaking before leaving for Brussels, Tsipras said he had not yet received any document.

Tsipras says he submitted his proposal to creditors on Monday night but gave no details of what fiscal reforms Greece was suggesting in return for its final bailout funds.

Elected in January on promises to repeal the deeply resented austerity measures Greece had to impose in return for its five-year bailout, Tsipras said his government had made concessions during the negotiations.

entry.title: Greek PM heads to Brussels to present latest deal proposal
entry.summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras leads a meeting at the Education Ministry in Athens, Tuesday, June 2, 2015.

entry.title: Greek PM heads to Brussels to present latest deal proposal
entry.summary:
Tsipras says Greece has submitted a proposal for an agreement with its creditors, as Athens seeks a deal that will to unlock desperately needed rescue money.

Tsipras was invited to Brussels by European Commission head Jean Claude Juncker, with whom he was to meet for talks Wednesday evening, a Greek government official said.

entry.title: Uncertainty shrouds Greek debt talks after Tsipras tirade
entry.summary:
In an article in the French daily Le Monde which European diplomats said appeared intended to show Greek voters how hard he was fighting, Tsipras accused the lenders of making "absurd proposals" and disregarding Greek democracy.

Referring to creditors' demands for further pension cuts and rejection of restoring collective wage bargaining, Tsipras said they amounted to "the complete abolition of democracy in Europe" and the creation of a "technocratic monstrosity".

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras Insists "Very Close" to Deal With Lenders
entry.summary:
Speaking an annual financial conference in Athens, Tsipras said the government had not abandoned its goal to try and persuade lenders to restructure Greece's debt.

"It appears that we have reached common ground with the institutions on a number of issues, and that makes us optimistic that we are really very close to an agreement," Tsipras said, noting convergence on harmonized sales tax rates and tax administration reforms.

The 40-year-old Tsipras won January elections promising undo austerity measures that stabilized public finances but cause a massive drop in output, triggering a wave of poverty and unemployment.

entry.title: Greece's Tsipras says "very close" to deal with lenders
Tsipras presses for early Greek debt deal but flags referendum
entry.summary:
But Tsipras also said he would have to resort to a referendum if lenders insisted on demands deemed unacceptable by his leftist government, elected to scrap austerity.

Pressed on the options if no deal were found, Tsipras ruled out snap elections but said the government did not have the right to accept demands that fell outside the limits of its mandate and would have to ask Greeks to decide.

The moves effectively took the talks out of the hands of Varoufakis, although Tsipras defended the flamboyant intellectual, while acknowledging that the mood towards Greece among euro zone finance ministers was sour.

Tsipras accused the previous conservative-led Greek government and unnamed forces in Europe of laying a "trap" for his government when it took power.

"They derive pleasure from the prospect of a failure in the talks," Tsipras said, saying his government had walked into a "minefield" when it took office.

The ECB barred banks from posting Greek government bonds as collateral to obtain funds in its regular monetary tenders in February, since Tsipras' government had vowed not to complete its international bailout program.

In another jibe against European partners, Tsipras said his government made a mistake by accepting a verbal rather than written commitment that the ECB decision would be reversed once Greece got a deal to extend its bailout.

entry.title: Greek Prime Minister Tsipras Rules out Early Elections If Bailout Talks With Creditors Fail
Merkel to press Greece's Tsipras for progress on reforms
entry.summary:
"At the highest level, the Germans want to keep Greece in the euro area and find a solution, but time is running short and there may have to be more drama before Tsipras can put his foot down and reach an agreement," one senior official said.

A Greek government official told Reuters in Athens that Tsipras would outline specific reforms to Merkel in a bid to appease creditors and is hoping she will intervene so that there is a breakthrough in the negotiations.

Tsipras, elected in January on an anti-austerity platform, is resisting cutting pensions, liberalizing the labor market or raising value-added tax on Greek holiday islands.

Tsipras' office said he would also have a private meeting with French President Francois Hollande on the summit sidelines.

entry.title: Putin gives visiting Greek PM Tsipras historic Greek icon
entry.summary: Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Putin presented the icon depicting St. Nicholas and St. Spyridon to Tsipras following Wednesday's talks at the Kremlin.

entry.title: Putin gives visiting Greek prime minister Tsipras an ancient Greek icon once stolen by Nazis
entry.summary: Speaking Thursday, Tsipras reaffirmed his opposition to Western sanctions slapped on Russia last year and said his government helped block proposals to strengthen the sanctions.

entry.title: Putin gives visiting Greek PM Tsipras ancient Greek icon
entry.summary:
Sergei Naryshkin, right, speaker of the State Duma, lower parliament chamber, right, welcomes Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Moscow, Russia, Thursday, April 9, 2015.

Greece's international creditors are watching Tsipras' visit to Russia with concern amid speculation that Greece might seek aid from Russia, as a bargaining chip with Western creditors.

Speaking to students, Tsipras said he and Putin have found a way to resume Greek agricultural exports, which were blocked last year under Russia's ban on Western food in retaliation to the EU sanctions.

entry.title: Putin meets with Greece's Tsipras
Tsipras and Putin agree closer ties at Moscow talks
entry.summary: The EU Parliament's president has warned Tsipras not to break the line on EU sanctions towards Russia.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras in Moscow for talks
Tsipras heads to Moscow, Europeans keeping wary eye on visit
entry.summary:
Alexis Tsipras' government " a coalition of the radical left and nationalist right elected in January on promises to repeal the austerity measures imposed as a condition of the rescue " has been flirting with Moscow from the start.

Moscow hopes talks with Tsipras will help further weaken the EU's resolve to maintain the sanctions against Russia, said Sergei Oznobishchev, head of Russia's independent Institute of Strategic Assessment.

entry.title: Tsipras heads to Moscow, Europeans keeping wary eye on visit
entry.summary:
Tough talk, particularly in relation to Greece's creditors, has made Tsipras' popularity soar at home, with many Greeks saying they have regained a sense of lost national pride.

But analysts warn Tsipras is playing a dangerous game, particularly if the tough talk reflects actual intentions rather than just rhetoric aimed at a domestic audience.

Tsipras has made no secret of his disagreement with the EU's position on Russia.

entry.title: Greece disagrees with sanctions against Russia, Tsipras says
entry.summary: "We do not agree with sanctions. I believe that this is a road to nowhere. I support the point of view that there is a need for a dialogue and diplomacy," Tsipras added.

entry.title: Greece disagrees with sanctions against Russia, Tsipras says
entry.summary:
Greece's new government disagrees with sanctions against Russia, and wants to boost trade ties with the country, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said before a visit to Moscow next week.

France and Germany on Tuesday downplayed Tsipras' upcoming visit to Moscow, where he will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on April 8.

entry.title: Merkel and Tsipras meet, but little sign of debt progress
entry.summary: Tsipras said Merkel invited him to Berlin for talks as the tensions between the two countries increased, telling him "it is better to talk with one another than about one another."

entry.title: Tsipras, Merkel urge end to name-calling
entry.summary:
Tsipras said the budget cuts and structural reforms demanded over the last five years in exchange for two bailout programmes had not been a "success story" but rather brought his country to its knees.

As tensions have flared, painful historical memories have resurfaced, with Tsipras's government reviving reparation claims for the Nazi occupation of Greece in World War II.

In his opening statement, Tsipras stressed that Greece did not see the case as closed, insisting that it was a "moral issue" that must still be resolved.

entry.title: A glance at issues that divide Germany and Greece as new PM Tsipras makes 1st visit to Berlin
entry.summary:
BERLIN - Relations between Greece's new government and Germany got off to a rocky start after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras swept to power in January on pledges to end the budget austerity Germany had been pushing for.

Here are some of the issues causing friction as Tsipras makes his first visit to Berlin to meet Chancellor Angela Merkel.

Tsipras' left-wing party argues that austerity has been counterproductive but agreed a month ago to push through reforms in exchange for keeping European Union aid flowing.

entry.title: Greek debt 'impossible' to repay: Tsipras
entry.summary: Tsipras is to meet Merkel in Berlin later on Monday.

entry.title: Tsipras on first trip to Germany amid tense relations
entry.summary: Tsipras' party won general elections in January after campaigning against the spending cuts favored by Germany in exchange for 240 billion euros ($260 billion) in international bailout money.

entry.title: Tsipras on first trip to Germany amid tense relations
entry.summary:
"I did not come here to ask for financial help," Tsipras told reporters after meeting with Merkel behind closed doors for more than an hour.

Merkel was careful to point out Germany was only one of the eurozone nations that would be responsible for deciding whether Greece's reforms are sufficient, and said no decisions had been made in her talks with Tsipras.

entry.title: Tsipras on first trip to Germany amid tense relations
Tsipras visits Germany for first time as Greek leader as countries seek to mend relations
entry.summary:
BERLIN - Alexis Tsipras is visiting Germany for the first time since becoming Greece's prime minister as his debt-ridden country and its key creditor seek to halt a downward spiral in relations.

Last week, Merkel and other European leaders told Tsipras to come up soon with budget cuts and tax increases that would enable him to get more bailout money.

Tsipras' first few weeks in office have been marked by tensions over the two governments' contrasting approaches to the debt crisis and Athens' revival of calls for World War II reparations from Berlin.

entry.title: Greek PM Tsipras says more optimistic after talks
entry.summary: "I'm more optimistic after this deliberation. I think that all the sides confirmed their intention to try to do their best to overcome the difficulties of the Greek economy as soon as possible," Tsipras said on leaving the talks in Brussels.

entry.title: Greek leader defiant ahead of bailout meeting
entry.summary: Tsipras spoke in parliament before lawmakers approved an anti-poverty bill, the first piece of legislation from the left-wing government elected on Jan. 25.

entry.title: Greek leader defiant ahead of bailout meeting
entry.summary: Although there has been no formal response to Tsipras' request for the emergency meeting with Merkel and Hollande, Greek government spokesman Gavriil Sakellaridis indicated that it would go ahead.
